text: We next investigated whether repeated strong TCR activation is a compensatory signal for <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling in the induction of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Th1 cells .

For this , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells were differentiated for 2 consecutive weeks with high antigen doses in the presence or absence of <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> throughout ( Figures 4A-4D ) .

High antigen dose and <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cooperated to induce maximal <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production ( Figures 4A and 4B ) , given that this combination resulted in the highest numbers of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - producing Th1 cells .

text: To determine the requirements for stability of the <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - producing Th1 cells , we differentiated <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells for 1 week with high antigen doses with or without <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figures 4A and 4C ) , washed them , and then restimulated them for an additional week with a low antigen dose , in the absence or presence of <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 4F ) .
